column1: Tifton is a city in Tift County
column4: 350 at the 2010 census. The city is the county seat of Tift County.The area's public schools are administered by the Tift County School District. Abraham Baldwin Agricultural College has its main campus in Tifton. Southern Regional Technical College and the University of Georgia also have Tifton campuses.

column1: Sites in the area include the Coastal Plain Research Arboretum
column3: and the Georgia Museum of Agriculture & Historic Village. The Tifton Residential Historic District is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Tifton is located in south central Georgia along Interstate 75
column2: which runs north to south through the city
column3: leading north 167 mi (269 km) to Atlanta and south 45 mi (72 km) to Valdosta. Other highways that pass through the city include U.S. Route 41

column1: Henry Tift Myers AirportHenry Tift Myers Airport (IATA: TMA
column3: FAA LID: TMA) is a public airport located two miles (3 km) southeast of Tifton
column5: with no scheduled commercial airline service.

column1: Tifton was founded in 1872 in Berrien County at the junction of the Georgia Southern and Florida Railroad and the Brunswick and Western Railroad by sawmill owner Henry H. Tift.  Tifton was incorporated as a city in 1890.  In 1905
column2: it was designated county seat of the newly formed Tift County.

column1: Several Chicago-Florida passenger trains made stops in Tifton: the Atlantic Coast Line's Seminole
column2: Flamingo and City of Miami and the Southern Railway's Ponce de Leon and Royal Palm. With the discontinuance of the Royal Palm in 1970
column3: Tifton was left without passenger service.

column1: The Tifton Gazette is a thrice-weekly newspaper published in Tifton
column2: Georgia. It is operated by South Georgia Media Group
column3: a division of Community Newspaper Holdings Inc. The Tifton Grapevine   is a twice-weekly online newspaper with an email circulation of 5
column4: 800. It is operated by Sayles Unlimited Marketing.

column1: Georgia Museum of Agriculture & Historic VillageUntil recently
column2: Tifton was the home of the world's second largest magnolia tree
column3: which was located in Magnolia Tree Park. In 2004
column4: the tree was burned in a fire. The cause of the fire has never been given by local authorities. Currently
column5: the tree and observation area are blocked from visitors by a gate.  Although it no longer grows
column6: the tree still stands. It is not known where the new second largest magnolia tree resides.

column1: === Georgia Museum of Agriculture & Historic Village ===
The Georgia Museum of Agriculture & Historic Village
column5: 1976. The grounds consist of five areas: a traditional farm community of the 1870s
column9: and national peanut complex; and the Museum of Agriculture Center. Over 35 structures have been relocated to the 95-acre (380
column10: 000 m2) site and faithfully restored or preserved. Costumed interpreters explain and demonstrate the lifestyle and activities of this time in Georgia's history.

column1: The Tifton Residential Historic District was listed on the National Register of Historic Places on April 30
column2: 2008. It is bounded generally by 14th Street
column4: 2nd Street and Forrest Avenue at coordinates 31°27′35″N 83°30′25″W.  The Tifton Commercial Historic District and the Tift County Courthouse are also on the National Register.
